revision.text:
The '''Norwegian Football Cup 1986''' was won by [[Tromsø Idrettslag|Tromsø]] after they beat [[Lillestrøm Sportsklubb|Lillestrøm]] in the cup final. ==Final== {{footballbox |date = 26 October 1986 |time = |team1 =[[Tromsø Idrettslag|Tromsø]] |score =4–1 (2–0) |report = |team2 =[[Lillestrøm Sportsklubb|Lillestrøm]] |goals1 =[[Nils Solstad]] {{goal|2}}
[[Lars Espejord]] {{goal|7}}
[[Truls Jenssen]] {{goal|65}}
[[Tore Rismo]] {{goal|74}} |goals2 =[[Bård Bjerkeland]] {{goal|50}} |stadium =[[Ullevaal Stadion]] |attendance =22 000 |referee =[[Egil Nervik]] ([[Sportsklubben Freidig|Freidig]]) |penalties1 = |penaltyscore = |penalties2 = }} '''Tromsø's winning team''': [[Bjarte Flem]], ([[Gunnar Gamst]] 89), [[Nils Solstad]], [[Tore Nilsen (footballer)|Tore Nilsen]], [[Tor H. Pedersen]], [[Trond Steinar Albertsen]], [[Truls Jenssen]], [[Tore Rismo]], [[Sigmund Forfang]], [[Trond Johansen]], [[Per-Mathias Høgmo]], ([[Yngvar Bendiksen]] 87),
'''Lillestrøm's team''': [[Arne Amundsen]], [[Ole Dyrstad]], [[Tor Inge Smedås]], [[Bård Bjerkeland]], [[Gunnar Halle]], [[Rune Richardsen]], [[Kjetil Osvold]], [[Tom Sundby]], [[Bjarne Sognnæs]], [[Sten Glenn Håberg]] and [[André Krogsæter]]. ==References== *[http://www.rsssf.no/1986/fcup http://www.rsssf.no] {{Norwegian Football Cup}} {{1985–86 in European football (UEFA)}} {{1986–87 in European football (UEFA)}} [[Category:Norwegian Football Cup seasons]] [[Category:1986 domestic association football cups|Norway]] [[Category:1986 in Norwegian football|Football Cup]] {{Norway-footy-competition-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox cycling race report | name = 2009 GP Ouest-France | previous = [[2008 GP Ouest-France|2008]] | next = [[2010 GP Ouest-France|2010]] | image = | image_caption = | series = [[2009 UCI World Ranking]] | race_no = 22 | season_no = 24 | date = August 23 | stages = 1 | distance = 229.2 | unit = km | time = | speed = | first = [[Simon Gerrans]] | first_nat = AUS | first_natvar = | first_team = {{ct|CTT|2009}} | second = [[Pierrick Fédrigo]] | second_nat = FRA | second_natvar = | second_team = {{ct|BBO|2009}} | third = [[Paul Martens]] | third_nat = GER | third_natvar = | third_team = {{ct|RAB|2009}} }} The '''2009 [[GP Ouest-France]]''' was a one-day [[road bicycle racing|road race]] which took place on 23 August 2009 in [[Plouay]], [[France]]. The race was held over {{convert|229|km|mi}}, which is 12 laps of a circuit. 2009 was the fifth time that the race has been part of the [[UCI ProTour]], but the race can be dated back to 1931 at its present location. The race was won by the Australian [[Simon Gerrans]], his first victory in a major one-day race. Frenchman [[Pierrick Fédrigo]] came in second, with [[Paul Martens]] of Germany coming in third. Gerrans won a sprint from a five-man breakaway group which also included [[Anthony Roux]] of France and [[Dan Martin (cyclist)|Dan Martin]] of Ireland. ==Results== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccccff;" !Rank !Cyclist !Team !Time ![[2009 UCI World Ranking|UCI World Ranking]]
Points |- !1 |'''{{flagathlete|[[Simon Gerrans]]|AUS}} |'''{{ct|CTT|2009}}''' |'''5h 58' 53"''' |align="center"|'''80''' |- !2 |{{flagathlete|[[Pierrick Fédrigo]]|FRA}} |{{ct|BBO|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|60 |- !3 |{{flagathlete|[[Paul Martens]]|GER}} |{{ct|RAB|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|50 |- !4 |{{flagathlete|[[Anthony Roux]]|FRA}} |{{ct|FDJ|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|40 |- !5 |{{flagathlete|[[Dan Martin (cyclist)|Dan Martin]]|IRL}} |{{ct|GRM|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|30 |- !6 |{{flagathlete|[[Luis Leon Sanchez Gil]]|ESP}} |{{ct|GCE|2009}} |align="right"|+ 3" |align="center"|22 |- !7 |{{flagathlete|[[Samuel Dumoulin]]|FRA}} |{{ct|COF|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|14 |- !8 |{{flagathlete|[[Maxim Iglinsky]]|KAZ}} |{{ct|AST|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|10 |- !9 |{{flagathlete|[[Frédéric Guesdon]]|FRA}} |{{ct|FDJ|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|6 |- !10 |{{flagathlete|[[Jesús Del Nero]]|ESP}} |{{ct|FUJ|2009}} |align="right"|s.t. |align="center"|2 |} == External links == * [http://www.uciprotour.com/templates/UCI/UCI5/layout.asp?MenuId=MTU2MTM&LangId=1 2009 GP Ouest-France] {{2009 UCI World Ranking}} {{GP Ouest-France}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gp Ouest-France, 2009}} [[Category:GP Ouest-France|2009]] [[Category:2009 UCI World Ranking]] [[Category:2009 in French sport]] [[Category:2009 UCI ProTour|GP Ouest-France]] {{Cycling-race-stub}} {{France-sport-stub}}

{{about|the 2016–17 snow skiing events and results|other sports' results|2017 in sports}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Year nav topic5|2017|skiing|sports}}
From July 1, 2016 to April 23, 2017, the following [[skiing]] events took place at various locations around the world.
==Alpine skiing== ===World Championships (Alpine)=== * January 22–31 [[2017 World Para Alpine Skiing Championships]] in {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Tarvisio]]<ref>[https://www.paralympic.org/tarvisio-2017 IPC's 2017 World Para Alpine Skiing Championships Page]</ref> ** For results, click [https://www.paralympic.org/tarvisio-2017/schedule-results/info-live-results/as1o17/eng/zz/engzz_alpine-skiing-daily-competition-schedule.htm here.] * February 6–19: [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2017]] in {{flagicon|SWI}} [[St. Moritz]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.stmoritz2017.ch/en/ |title=FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2017 Website |access-date=March 22, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213015853/http://www.stmoritz2017.ch/en/ |archive-date=February 13, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ** {{AUT}} and {{SUI}} won 3 gold medals each. Austria won the overall medal tally. * March 6–14: 2017 [[World Junior Alpine Skiing Championships]] in {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Åre]]<ref>[https://data.fis-ski.com/dynamic/event-details.html?event_id=39412&cal_suchsector=AL FIS' 2017 World Junior Alpine Skiing Championships Results Page]</ref> ** {{AUT}} and {{SUI}} won 3 gold medals each. Austria won the overall medal tally.

{{infobox country at games | NOC = ARG | NOCname = [[Argentine Olympic Committee]] | games = Winter Olympics | year = 1948 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.coarg.org.ar }} {{es icon}} | location = [[St. Moritz]] | competitors = 9 (men) | sports = 2 | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = 1928 | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Argentina]]''' competed at the '''[[1948 Winter Olympics]]''' in [[St. Moritz]], [[Switzerland]]. It was only the second time that Argentinian athletes had competed at the Winter Games, after missing the [[1932 Winter Olympics]] and the [[1936 Winter Olympics]]. ==Alpine skiing== {{main|Alpine skiing at the 1948 Winter Olympics}} ;Men {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Race 1 !colspan="2"|Race 2 !colspan="2"|Total |- !Time !Rank !Time !Rank !Time !Rank |- |[[Julio Cernuda]] |rowspan="6"|Downhill |colspan="4" bgcolor="wheat"| |align="center"|4:46.4 |align="center"|95 |- |[[Pablo Rosenkjer]] |colspan="4" bgcolor="wheat"| |align="center"|4:36.2 |align="center"|93 |- |[[Gino de Pellegrín]] |colspan="4" bgcolor="wheat"| |align="center"|4:25.2 |align="center"|91 |- |[[Otto Jung]] |colspan="4" bgcolor="wheat"| |align="center"|4:09.3 |align="center"|85 |- |[[Luis de Ridder]] |colspan="4" bgcolor="wheat"| |align="center"|3:50.2 |align="center"|68 |- |[[Justo del Carril]] |colspan="4" bgcolor="wheat"| |align="center"|3:46.2 |align="center"|63 |- |[[Otto Jung]] |rowspan="4"|Slalom |align="center"|1:54.1 |align="center"|56 |align="center"|1:21.6 |align="center"|46 |align="center"|3:15.7 |align="center"|53 |- |[[Pablo Rosenkjer]] |align="center"|1:53.7 (+0:05) |align="center"|55 |align="center"|1:34.2 |align="center"|55 |align="center"|3:27.9 |align="center"|56 |- |[[Luis de Ridder]] |align="center"|1:32.2 |align="center"|44 |align="center"|1:20.2 |align="center"|41 |align="center"|2:52.4 |align="center"|42 |- |[[Gino de Pellegrín]] |align="center"|1:29.8 |align="center"|40 |align="center"|1:23.5 |align="center"|47 |align="center"|2:53.3 |align="center"|43 |} '''Men's combined''' The downhill part of this event was held along with the main medal event of downhill skiing. revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event |name = B.C. Highland Games and Scottish Festival |logo = New BC Highland Games and Scottish Festival logo.jpeg | logo_size = 100px |logo_caption = New official logo of BC Highland Games and Scottish Festival |image = File:Highland Dancers.jpg|Highland Dancers File:Heavy event athletes.jpg|Heavy event athletes File:Massed pipe bands.jpg|Massed pipe bands at BC Highland Games and Scottish Festival |caption = |location = [[Percy Perry Stadium]]
[[Coquitlam]], [[British Columbia]] |years_active = |dates = Last Saturday in June |genre = [[Highland games]] |website = [http://www.bchighlandgames.com/ BCHighlandGames.com] }} The '''[http://bchighlandgames.com/ B.C. Highland Games and Scottish Festival]''' is the second oldest continually running [[Highland Games]] in [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]]. The games are run by the BC Highland Games Committee under the auspices of the United Scottish Cultural Society, out of the Scottish Cultural Centre in [[Vancouver, British Columbia|Vancouver]]. In 2019, an expanded Games with more events and activities will be held on June 14 & 15, 2019 at nearby Lafarge Lake Park in Coquitlam, steps from the Lafarge Skytrain stn. In 2019, the Games will be situated in a grassy and shaded park, more suitable for a highland games. Scottish heavy events (caber tossing), pipe bands, highland dancers, whisky school, Celtic artisans, kids activities, stock dog sheep herding (TBD), live Celtic entertainment, beer garden, cultural activities, talks, workshops. Massed bands at end of day. Traditional events include: * [[bagpipes|Solo Piping]] * Solo Drumming * Pipe Bands * Performance Pipe Bands * [[Scottish highland dance|Highland Dancing]] * Whisky tasting * Children's activities * Haggis hunting * Heavy Events, which include: **[[Stone put]] **[[Weight throw]] **[[Scottish hammer throw]] **[[Weight over the bar]] **[[Sheaf toss]] **[[Caber toss]] **Farmers walk * [[Piobaireachd]] competition * Beer garden * Food & product vendors * Main stage entertainers/performers ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.bchighlandgames.com/ Official Site] [[Category:Sport in Coquitlam]] [[Category:Culture of Coquitlam]] [[Category:Highland games]] [[Category:Multi-sport events in Canada]] [[Category:Sports festivals in Canada]] [[Category:Folk festivals in Canada]]

'''BC Lavera'''
(1993–1995) | arena = Sports hall "Kausta" | capacity = 500 | location = [[Kaunas]], [[Lithuania]] | colors = Orange, white and purple {{color box|#FF4500}} {{color box|#FFFFFF}} {{color box|#9260a5}} | president = [[Gintaras Verpetinskas]] | coach = [[Henrikas Giedraitis]] | championships = | website = | h_pattern_b = _basket_with_white | h_body = FF4500 | h_pattern_s = _basket_with_white | h_shorts = FF4500 }} '''Basketball club Lavera''' ({{lang-lt|Krepšinio klubas Lavera}}) was a [[basketball]] club located in [[Kaunas]], [[Lithuania]]. It was founded in 1991 and participated in the first two seasons of the [[Lietuvos krepšinio lyga|Lithuanian Basketball League]]. Despite the club's success, Lavera dissolved in 1995 due to financial issues.{{cite web|title=Išnykusių LKL klubų istorijoje – skandalų šleifas|url=http://www.delfi.lt/krepsinis/herojai/isnykusiu-lkl-klubu-istorijoje-skandalu-sleifas.d?id=70244216|website=Delfi.lt|accessdate=23 July 2017|language=lt-LT}} ==Season by season== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Season !League !Pos. !Roster |- | style="background:#efefef;"|'''[[1993–94 LKL season|1993–94]]''' | [[Lithuanian Basketball League|LKL]] | 4th | [[Ramūnas Cvirka]], [[Ramūnas Inokaitis]], [[Rolandas Spudvilas]], [[Dainius Staugaitis]], [[Arūnas Rozenbergas]], [[Tomas Pačėsas]], [[Singaras Tribė]], [[Rolandas Mačiulaitis]], [[Andrius Vyšniauskas]], [[Gediminas Meiliūnas]], [[Nerijus Rimkevičius]], [[Virgijus Praškevičius]] |- | style="background:#efefef;"|'''[[1994–95 LKL season|1994–95]]''' | [[Lithuanian Basketball League|LKL]] | style="background:#BBF3BB;"|3rd | [[Ramūnas Cvirka]], [[Dainius Staugaitis]], [[Žydrūnas Urbonas]], [[Gintaras Staniulis]], [[Arūnas Rozenbergas]], [[Tomas Pačėsas]], [[Singaras Tribė]], [[Erikas Bublys]], [[Andrius Vyšniauskas]], [[Gediminas Meiliūnas]], [[Šarūnas Budrys]], [[Virginijus Praškevičius]] |- |} ::Detailed information of former rosters and results.{{cite web|title=Lavera {{!}} Lietuvos krepšinio lyga|url=http://www.lkl.lt/komanda/205242/?seasonId=88351#stf|website=LKL.lt|accessdate=23 July 2017|language=lt-LT}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{LKL}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dzukija}} [[Category:Basketball teams in Lithuania]] [[Category:Sport in Kaunas]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Lithuania]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in 1991]] {{Europe-basketball-team-stub}} {{Lithuania-sport-stub}}

{{No footnotes|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox Organization |name = División Mayor del Fútbol Profesional Colombiano |image = Dimayor Colombia logo.svg |image_border = |size = 150px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = DIMAYOR |motto = |formation = 1948 |extinction = |type = Sports organization |status = |purpose = [[Association football|Football]] |headquarters = |location = [[Bogotá]] |region_served = [[Colombia]] |membership = 36 affiliated clubs |language = Spanish |leader_title = President |leader_name = Jorge Enrique Vélez |main_organ = General Assembly |parent_organization = |affiliations = [[FIFA]]
[[CONMEBOL]]
[[Colombian Football Federation|FCF]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.dimayor.com.co www.dimayor.com.co] |remarks = }} The '''División Mayor del Fútbol Profesional Colombiano''' ({{lang-en|Major Division of Colombian Professional Football}}), also known by the truncation '''DIMAYOR''', is an organization responsible for organizing and operating professional [[association football|football]] leagues and tournaments in [[Colombia]]. It administers the top two levels of professional football leagues in Colombia, the [[Categoría Primera A|Primera A]] and the [[Categoría Primera B|Primera B]], as well as the [[Colombian Superliga]] and [[Copa Colombia]], Colombia's main national cup. ==External links== * [http://www.dimayor.com.co Official website] {{es icon}} * [http://www.fcf.com.co Federación Colombiana de Fútbol's official website] {{es icon}} {{Football in Colombia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Division Mayor del Futbol Profesional Colombiano}} [[Category:Association football governing bodies in South America]] [[Category:Sports organisations of Colombia]] {{footy-org-stub}} {{Colombia-sport-stub}}

[[CAF Confederation Cup]]
[[CAF Super Cup|Super Cup]]
[[FIFA Club World Cup]]
[[FIFA World Cup]](National Team)
[[African Cup of Nations]](National Team) | match = | league = }} Football is by far the most popular sport in Chad.{{cite web|author=William Echikson |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1983/0831/083145.html |title=In summer, Parisians are intent on soccer - not Chad war |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-03}}{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/world-travel-guide-interesting-facts-chad-sub-7443278.html?cat=37 |title=World Travel Guide: Interesting Facts About Chad (sub-Saharan Africa) - Yahoo Voices |publisher=voices.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-03}}{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/football/index_intro_33945.html |title=2006 FIFA World Cup - Mahamat Ali, 13, finds an outlet in football at a Chad refugee camp |publisher=UNICEF |date= |accessdate=2013-12-03}} Many of top Chadian footballers have played professionally in [[Football in France|France]]. According to one source, [[Nambatingue Tokomon]], known as "Toko," played for renowned French soccer clubs, including [[Paris St. Germain]], in the 1970s and 1980s. [[Abdoulay Karateka]] also played for Paris St. Germain. [[Japhet N'Doram|Ndoram Japhet]] played for [[F.C. Nantes Atlantique|Nantes]] and [[Monaco]] in the 1990s." The [[Chad national football team|national team]] represents football in Chad internationally, however, the squad has never qualified for the [[FIFA World Cup]] or the [[African Cup of Nations]]. They did not enter qualification tournaments for the World Cup until 2002. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Football in Chad}} {{Football in Africa}} [[Category:Football in Chad| ]] {{Chad-sport-stub}} {{footy-stub}}

{{for|the rugby union competition|Hampshire Cup (rugby union)}} {{Infobox football tournament | name = Hampshire Senior Cup | logo = [[IMage:Fa county hampshire.png]] | founded = 1887 | number of teams = varies | region = [[Hampshire]], [[Isle of Wight]], [[Dorset]], [[Wiltshire]], [[Channel Islands]] | current champions = [[Havant & Waterlooville F.C.]] (2 titles) | most successful club = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] (17 titles) | website = [http://www.hampshirefa.com/FixturesAndResults/CountyCups/SaturdaySeniorCup/ Hampshire Senior Cup] }} The '''Hampshire Senior Cup''' is a [[Single-elimination tournament|cup competition]] open to [[association football|football]] teams affiliated with the [[Hampshire Football Association]]. The competition was founded in 1887 and has been contested every year since, with the exception of 1914 to 1919 when it was postponed due to the First World War.{{cite web|url=http://www.hampshirefa.com/FixturesAndResults/CountyCups/SaturdaySeniorCup/Archive/2008-2009/SaturdaySeniorCup.htm?js=1&tab=about|title=Hampshire Senior Cup – Previous Winners|publisher=[[Hampshire Football Association]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303001755/http://www.hampshirefa.com/FixturesAndResults/CountyCups/SaturdaySeniorCup/Archive/2008-2009/SaturdaySeniorCup.htm?js=1&tab=about|archivedate=3 March 2012}} Despite the name, teams from Wiltshire, Dorset, the Isle of Wight and the Channel Islands have also competed in this competition,{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/jersey/content/articles/2004/11/07/football_countycups_report_11_06_feature.shtml | title=Win, draw and defeat in County Cups | publisher=BBC | date=2004-11-07 | accessdate=2008-02-01}} as well as teams representing the Police and any armed forces based within the county. The competition is open to teams from all levels of competition from the [[Premier League]] down to Level 10 of the [[English football league system]], and a number of league teams have won this competition in the past. However, it is mostly non-league clubs who compete for this trophy instead of their league counterparts as all teams associated with the Hampshire FA are required to compete, with the exception of Premier League and [[English Football League]] teams who may opt out of the competition for a nominal fee.{{cite web | url = http://www.hampshirefa.com/NR/rdonlyres/3908BF58-718C-4CA2-80CC-8C912B4F6B9D/0/HampshireFACountyCupRules.doc | title = County Cup Competition Rules | publisher = Hampshire Football Association | accessdate = 15 April 2010 | format = DOC | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090529222251/http://www.hampshirefa.com/NR/rdonlyres/3908BF58-718C-4CA2-80CC-8C912B4F6B9D/0/HampshireFACountyCupRules.doc | archivedate = 29 May 2009 | df = dmy-all }} The current champions are [[Havant & Waterlooville F.C.|Havant & Waterlooville]], who defeated [[Winchester City]] on penalties, after the game finished 1-1 after 90 minutes, in the 2016 final held at [[St Mary's Stadium]], Southampton. Havant and Waterlooville F.C. also won 2018 HSC by defeating Blackfield and Langley in a 3-0 win at St Mary’s once again. In April 2012, [[FIFA]] announced that the [[Hawk-Eye]] sensor system would be used in an experimental capacity at that year's final between [[A.F.C. Totton]] and [[Eastleigh F.C.|Eastleigh]] as part of a series of ongoing reliability and accuracy tests of goal-line technology systems.{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/apr/27/fifa-goalline-technology | title=Fifa to test goalline technology in Hampshire FA Senior Cup final | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | date=27 April 2012 | accessdate=15 May 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/sport/9674664.FIFA_to_experiment_at_Hampshire_Senior_Cup_final/ | title=FIFA to experiment at Hampshire Senior Cup final | publisher=[[Southern Daily Echo]] | date=27 April 2012 | accessdate=15 May 2012}} On the 9 October 2013, a tie was played between [[Brockenhurst F.C.|Brockenhurst]] and [[Andover Town F.C.|Andover Town]]. After the match finished 0-0 after extra time, the subsequent [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] resulted in 29 consecutive goals being scored, with Brockenhurst winning 15-14. This was later confirmed by [[the Football Association]] as an English record (and possibly a world record) for the highest number of consecutive goals scored in a penalty shootout.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24535150|title=Penalty shoot-out record: Brockenhurst 15-14 Andover|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|first=Nabil|last=Hassan|date=15 October 2013|accessdate=16 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/brockenhurst-and-andover-town-score-29-consecutive-penalties-to-set-new-record-8882084.html|work=[[The Independent]]|first=Simon|last=Rice|title=Brockenhurst and Andover Town score 29 consecutive penalties to set new record|date=15 October 2013|accessdate=16 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2013/oct/15/penalty-shootout-record-shooting-goals-barrel-video|title=Penalty shootout record: like shooting goals in a barrel?|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=15 October 2013|accessdate=16 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/pitchside-europe/non-league-sides-set-penalty-shoot-record-160337267.html|title=Non-league sides set penalty shoot-out record|work=[[Eurosport]]|date=15 October 2013|accessdate=16 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018052759/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/pitchside-europe/non-league-sides-set-penalty-shoot-record-160337267.html|archivedate=18 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==Winners== ===By team=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Victories !Team !First Win !Last Win |- valign="top" |17 |[[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]

{{Infobox American football team | name = Helsinki 69ers | logo = Helsinki 69ers Logo 2014.png | logosize = 200px | helmet = | helmetsize = | established = 1991 | folded = | location = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] | stadium = [[Helsinki Velodrome]] | coach = {{flagicon|USA}} Jason Thomas | manager = {{flagicon|FIN}} Jukka Rantala | league = [[Vaahteraliiga]] | division = | league_champs = | div_champs = | h_pattern_h =_af | h_pattern_la = | h_pattern_b = _whitesleevelinesandsides | h_pattern_ra = | h_pattern_p = | h_pattern_s =_af | h_helmet = 000000 | h_leftarm = 000000 | h_body = 000000 | h_rightarm = 000000 | h_pants =000000 | h_socks = FFFFFF | h_title = Home kit | a_pattern_h =_af | a_pattern_la = | a_pattern_b = | a_pattern_ra = | a_pattern_p = | a_pattern_s =_af | a_helmet = 000000 | a_leftarm = FFFFFF | a_body = FFFFFF | a_rightarm = FFFFFF | a_pants = 000000 | a_socks = FFFFFF | a_title = Away kit }}
The '''Helsinki 69ers''' are an [[American football]] club from [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]]. The club was formed in 1991, and its men's first team is currently playing in [[Vaahteraliiga]], the top tier of American football in Finland.
== History == The Helsinki 69ers were formed in 1991. The team started in the lower divisions of Finnish American football and slowly made its way up to [[Finnish 1st Division (American football)|1st Division]]. The 69ers played 10 seasons in the division, and in 2012, the 69ers won the 1st Division championship, the Spaghettibowl. 69ers won the final against [[Kouvola Indians]] with a score of 43-10. For the first time the 69ers had a chance to play in the [[Vaahteraliiga]], the highest level in Finland. The team played its first Vaahteraliiga game in [[2013 Vaahteraliiga season|2013 season]] against [[Vantaa TAFT|TAFT]], losing 41-14.<ref>{{cite web|title=Helsinki 69ers divarin mestaruuteen|url=http://www.gridiron.fi/blog/2012/08/18/helsinki-69ers-divarin-mestaruuteen/|website=gridiron.fi|publisher=Gridiron|accessdate=26 November 2014|language=Finnish|date=18 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=69ers - In English |url=http://www.69ers.fi/in-english/ |website=69ers.fi |publisher=Helsinki 69ers |accessdate=26 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530102516/http://www.69ers.fi/in-english/ |archivedate=30 May 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Helsinki 69ers Are Ready For The Maple League|url=http://www.touchdown-europe.net/2013/02/finland-helsinki-69ers-are-ready-for.html|website=Touchdown-europe.net|publisher=Touchdown Europe|accessdate=4 December 2014|date=19 February 2013}}</ref>
The club shares their stadium, the [[Helsinki Velodrome]], with two other football teams from Helsinki: the [[Helsinki Roosters]] and the [[Helsinki Wolverines]].
== Club Structure == The 69ers men's first team played in [[Vaahteraliiga]] in the 2014 season and placed sixth after the regular season, missing the playoffs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sarjataulukko - Vaahteraliiga 2014|url=http://www.sajl.org/selaus/sarjataulukko.php?sarja=1&kausi=2014|website=Salj.org|publisher=American Football Federation of Finland|accessdate=4 December 2014}}</ref>
The youth section of the club was founded in 2005. 69ers have five boys' youth teams: U11, U13, U15, U17 and U19.<ref>{{cite web|title=Juniorit|url=http://www.69ers.fi/juniorit/|website=69ers.fi|publisher=Helsinki 69ers|accessdate=26 November 2014|language=Finnish}}</ref>

page.title: Hot Rod Magazine Championship Drag Races

revision.text:
The '''Hot Rod Magazine Championship Drag Races''' were a series of [[drag racing]] events sponsored by ''[[Hot Rod Magazine]]'' between 1961 and 1969.<ref>Taylor, Thom. Untitled item in ''Hot Rod Magazine'', February 2017, p.11.</ref> It was considered "one of the most significant drag racing events" of that era.<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref>
==History== The races were held at [[Riverside International Raceway|Riverside Raceway]] in [[Riverside, California]] starting in 1961.<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref> The total prize value awarded was US$37,000, more than a [[National Hot Rod Association]] (NHRA) national event purse at the time, and included (at first) a brand new [[Ford Mustang (first generation)|Ford Mustang]].<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref> ''Hot Rod'' publisher [[Ray Brock]] and editor [[Bob Greene]] worked with NHRA to arrange a summer event that would not create a scheduling conflict.<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref>
Held over three days, and run under NHRA regulations, all the pro classes were hosted, including [[Top Fuel]], [[Top Gas]], and [[Top Alcohol]], and including [[Dragster (car)|dragster]], [[funny car]], [[Modified (drag racing)|modified]], and [[Altered (drag racing)|altered]].<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref> At the insistence of [[Wally Parks]], a full slate of [[Sportsman (drag racing)|Sportsman]] classes was also offered.<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref>
The 1964 winner was [[Gas Ronda]], in his {{convert|427|cid|abbr=on}}-powered [[Ford Fairlane (Americas)|Thunderbolt]], taking home a [[Plymouth Barracuda]] as part of the prize package.<ref>Burgess, Phil. "Remembering Gas Ronda", written 26 October 2017, at [https://www.nhra.com/news/2017/remembering-gas-ronda NHRA.com] (retrieved 16 September 2018)</ref>
In 1965, the championship first hosted A/FX (Factory Experimental) cars (which later evolved into funny cars).<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref> That year, in TF/D (Top Fuel Dragster), [[Don Prudhomme]] and [[Tom McEwen (drag racer)|Tom McEwen]] each turned in 7-second passes at {{convert|211|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, but ultimately, Top Fuel Eliminator (TFE) went to [[Jim Warren (drag racer)|Jim Warren]].<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref> That year's racing was also the subject of a film produced by ''Hot Rod'', "The Hot Rod Story—Drag Racing", narrated by [[Dick Enberg]].<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref>
At the 1966 championship, McEwen would win the Top Fuel title, while [[Mike Snively]] did (in [[Roland Leong]]'s [[Hawaiian (dragster)|''Hawaiian'']], with a 7.07 second pass at {{convert|221.66|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}) in 1967. In 1968, it went to [[Steve Carbone]] in the ''Atlas Oil Tool Special''. The final year the event was held, [[Larry Dixon, Sr.]] won TFE in [[Rattler (dragster)|''Rattler'']] (sponsored by [[Howard Cams]]).<ref>Taylor, p.11.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Sources== *Taylor, Thom. Untitled item in ''Hot Rod Magazine'', February 2017, p. 11.

revision.text:
'''Hydraulic exercise equipment''' is a form of [[exercise machine]] used in a number of [[strength training]] programs. They are most often found in [[circuit training]] gyms.
Hydraulic circuit training machines were first developed for The Henley Corporation in the 1970s,<ref>[http://www.shapesforwomen.com/hydraulicfitness.asp Shapes for Women]</ref> and are now becoming an increasingly popular form of exercise.
The fundamental principles behind these designs are based on [[fluid dynamics]]: Force that is applied at one point is transmitted to another point using an incompressible fluid known as hydraulic oil.<ref>[http://science.howstuffworks.com/hydraulic1.htm How Stuff Works Science edition]</ref>
For circuit training applications, each piece of equipment is specifically designed for a given exercise. The effort is applied through the range of motion of the exercise acts on a [[lever]] against a piston which moves linearly within a hydraulic cylinder. The cylinder is filled with hydraulic oil which is displaced by the motion of the piston, and is allowed to flow to the opposite side of the piston through an adjustable orifice.
Resistance to the motion is determined by the amount of effort applied and the adjustment size of the orifice. This is a key feature of this design and allows the resistance to be adjusted to an individual's strength level.<ref>[http://www.healthfxamerica.com/healthmaxpro/guide/index.html Healthmax Pro]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Exercise equipment]]

{{About|the internationally recognised version of indoor cricket|the variant of the game played exclusively in the United Kingdom|Indoor cricket (UK variant)}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox sport | name = Indoor cricket | image = A game of indoor cricket in progress in Canberra, 2011.jpg | imagesize = 250px | caption = A [[Bowling (cricket)|bowler]] bowling to a [[Batting (cricket)|batsman]]. | union = [[World Indoor Cricket Federation]] | first = 1970s | first team = | registered = | clubs = | team = 8 players per side | mgender = Mixed gender until under-13 upwards. | category = [[Team sport|Team]], [[Bat-and-ball games|Bat-and-ball]] | ball = [[Indoor cricket ball]], [[cricket bat]],
[[collapsible wicket]] | venue = [[Indoor cricket court]] }} '''Indoor cricket''' is a variant of and shares many basic concepts with [[cricket]]. The game is most often played between two teams each consisting of six or eight players.[http://www.cricket.com.au/pv_obj_cache/pv_obj_id_1732F3EF2E82622590956CD1084379E3E80F0A00/filename/Indoor-Cricket-Rule-Book.ashx "Rules of Indoor Cricket"] from ''Cricket Australia'' Several versions of the game have been in existence since the late 1960s, whilst the game in its present form began to take shape in the late 1970s and early 1980s.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/twenty20wc/content/story/309625.html "Shorter, simpler, sillier" in ''ESPNcricinfo''], 7 September 2007. Conventional cricket has been played indoors at [[Docklands Stadium]] in [[Melbourne]], Australia.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/221031.html "Article on enclosed Docklands Stadium"] from ''ESPNcricinfo'' The codified sport of indoor cricket is not to be confused with conventional cricket played indoors, or with other modified versions of cricket played indoors (see [[Indoor cricket#Other forms of indoor cricket|other forms of indoor cricket]] below). ==The game of indoor cricket== In terms of the concept of the game indoor cricket is similar to [[cricket]]. Like its outdoor cousin, indoor cricket involves two batsmen, a bowler and a team of fielders. The bowler ''bowls'' the ball to the batsmen who must score runs.[http://www.lords.org/laws-and-spirit/laws-of-cricket/ "Laws and Spirit of Cricket"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220005023/http://www.lords.org/laws-and-spirit/laws-of-cricket |date=20 February 2010 }} from ''MCC'' The team with the highest score at the end of the match wins. Despite these basic similarities, the game itself differs significantly from its traditional counterpart in several ways, most notably on the field of play and the means by which runs are obtained. ==International rules overview== ===Safety gear=== Just like every other sport, warm ups and stretching is a must. As a minimum, every player, including the fielders have to wear an abdominal guard (box), with the person bowling the ball as an exception. The batsman are required to play batting gloves, primarily for preventing the bat from slipping out of the hands. indoor batting gloves are readily available at cricket stores, however some indoor cricket facilities also provide basic non-slip gloves that can be shared during the game. Some players prefer to use hard ball batting gloves to prevent their hands from serious injury, as the indoor cricket ball can cause serious damage. One optional security gadget is the safety goggles, like the ones used in squash, to prevent any serious injury to the eyes. As the game speed is usually very fast and the play really rigorous, its is a demanding cardiovascular activity. It is recommended to have a doctor checkup before taking up indoor cricket, especially in advance age and/or with any medical conditions. Remember, it's fielders right of way when a shot is played, so the batsman/fielder has to be watchful to avoid collisions. Be mindful of the fact that indoor cricket cause more sporting injuries than casual outdoor cricket, due to the proximity of the ball and fielders. Therefore, a sports/team insurance is very important. Some indoor sports facilities provide these insurances as part of the indoor tournaments. ===Playing arena=== {{Main|Indoor cricket court}} The length of an indoor cricket [[cricket pitch|pitch]] is the same as a conventional cricket pitch, and has 3 [[stump (cricket)|stump]]s at each end, but there the similarities end. The arena is completely enclosed by tight netting, a few metres from each side and end of the pitch. The playing surface is normally artificial grass matting. Whilst the pitch is the same length, however, the [[batsman|batsmen]] do not have to run the entire length. The striker's [[crease (cricket)|crease]] is in the regulation place in front of the stumps, but the non-striker's crease is only halfway down the pitch. ===Players=== Indoor cricket is played between 2 teams of 8 players. Each player must [[bowling (cricket)|bowl]] 2 eight ball [[over (cricket)|over]]s, and bat in a partnership for 4 overs. A faster version of the game exists, where each side is reduced to 6 players and each innings lasts 12 overs instead of 16. ===Equipment=== The stumps used in indoor cricket are not, for obvious reasons, stuck in the ground. Instead, they are collapsible spring-loaded stumps that immediately spring back to the standing position when knocked over. The ball used in indoor cricket is a modified [[cricket ball]], with a softer centre. The ball also differs in that it is yellow to make it more obvious to see indoors against varied backgrounds. Both traditional outdoor cricket bats or more specialised lighter-weight indoor cricket bats may be used. The gloves are typically lightweight cotton with no protective padding on the outside. The palm-side of the gloves usually have embedded rubber dots to aid grip. ===Scoring=== Scoring in indoor cricket is dived into 4 types: physical runs, bonus runs, the usual extras/sundries and penalty-minus runs. Physical runs are scored by both batsmen completing a run from one crease to the other. Bonus runs are scored when the ball hits a net. Bonus scores for particular parts of the nets follow: *Zone A (front net – '''behind''' the keeper): 0 runs *Zone B (side nets between the striker's end and halfway down the pitch): 1 run *Zone C (side nets between halfway and the bowlers end): 2 runs *Zone D (back net – behind the bowler): 4 or 6 runs depending on the manner in which the ball hit the back net. **On the bounce: 4 runs **On the full: 6 runs *Zone B or C onto Zone D: 3 runs NB: For bonus runs to be scored, at least one physical run must be scored. The bonus runs are then added to the physical runs. For example, a batsman strikes the ball, hitting the back net on the full (6) and makes one physical run, for a total of 7 runs. Extras/sundries are the same as those in formal cricket and consist of wides, no balls etcetera. Penalty-minus runs are the set number of runs deducted from a team’s score for each dismissal. ===Dismissals=== A batsman can be dismissed in the same ways they can be in conventional cricket – with variations in the case of LBW and mankad (see below) – and with the exception of ''timed out''. When a batsman gets dismissed, however, five runs are deducted from their total and they continue to bat. Batsmen bat in pairs for 4 overs at a time, irrespective of whether they are dismissed. A player can also be "caught" by a ball rebounding off a net, except off a "six", as long as it has not previously touched the ground. This negates any physical or bonus runs that might have been awarded. A method of dismissal in indoor cricket that is far more prevalent than its outdoor counterpart is the [[mankad]]. A mankad is given out if the bowler completes their bowling action without releasing the ball, breaks the stumps at their end without letting go of the ball and the non-striker is out of their ground. Whilst [[Leg before wicket|lbw]] is a valid form of dismissal in indoor cricket, it is a far rarer occurrence in indoor than it is in outdoor cricket. A batsman can only be dismissed lbw if he does not offer a shot and the umpire is satisfied that the ball would then have hit the stumps. ===Officials=== Indoor cricket is officiated by one umpire who is situated outside of the playing area at the strike batsmen's end of the court. The umpire sits or stands on a raised platform that is usually 3 metres above ground level. Secondary officials (such as scorers or video umpires) have sometimes been utilised in national or international competition. ===Result=== The team with the higher score at the conclusion of each innings is declared the winner of the match. The second innings continues for a full 16 overs even if the batting side passes the first innings total due to the possibility of a side finishing behind a total even after they have surpassed it (see dismissals above). In most cases indoor cricket is played according to a skins system, where the batting partnerships from each innings are compared against one another and the higher of the two is deemed to have won the skin. For example, the second batting partnership in the first innings might score 5 runs whilst the second partnership in the second innings scores 10 – the latter would be deemed to have won the skin. The team that has won the greater of the four skins available is often awarded the win if the totals are tied. ==3 Dot balls Rule == Most indoor cricket centres employ a dot ball rule, where the scoreboard has to change at least every third ball. This means if the batsmen play 2 consecutive balls without a change in the scorecard (applies on multiple batsmen over multiple over), the scorecard has to change on the 3rd ball. It can be changed by batsman scoring a run, extra runs or in the case where a run is not scored on the 3rd consecutive ball, the batsman is declared out and 5 runs deducted off the score, hence changing the scorecard. ===Jackpot ball Rule=== Some indoor leagues have the first or last ball of a 'Skin' declared a jackpot ball. This means any runs scored on the jackpot ball will be doubled. e.g. if a '7' is hit, it will counted as 14 runs and if a wicket is lost, it will be counted as minus 10 runs. ==Types of match and competition== Indoor cricket is typically played either as a six- or eight-a-side match, and with six- or eight-ball overs respectively. The game can be played in men's, women's and mixed competitions. Permutations of the game include bonus overs (where the bonus score is double, dismissals result in seven (7) runs (cf. five (5) runs) being deducted from the team score and fielding restrictions removed.) ===Test Match=== Test indoor cricket is the highest standard of indoor cricket and is played between members of the [[World Indoor Cricket Federation]].[http://www.worldindoorcricketfederation.com/tournaments.html "International competition"] from ''WICF'' The first international Test matches were played between Australia and New Zealand in 1985. Those sides have since been joined on the international stage by England (1990), South Africa (1991), Zimbabwe (1998), Namibia (1998), India (2000), Pakistan (2000), Sri Lanka (2002), United Arab Emirates (2004), Wales (2007), France (2007), Guernsey (2007), Singapore (2013), Malaysia (2017). Test matches are usually played in a group of matches called a "series" featuring two to four nations. These series can consist of three to five matches and where more than two nations are involved, may also include a finals series. Matches played at [[Indoor Cricket World Cup|World Cup]] events are also considered Test matches. International competition is also organised for juniors and masters age groups. The matches are considered Test matches within their respective divisions. Since 1985, most Test series between Australia and New Zealand have played for the Trans Tasman trophy. Similarly, since 1990, Test series between Australia and England have been played for a trophy known as The Ashes, a name borrowed from [[The Ashes|the trophy]] contested by the same nations in outdoor cricket. ===National championships=== Each member nation of the WICF usually holds its own national titles. In Australia, states and territories compete in the Australian Indoor Cricket Championships (as well as the now defunct National League).[http://www.cricket.com.au/pv_obj_cache/pv_obj_id_4C91902E0F9238F8826941738C20444DD2010500/filename/2012%20AJC%20Tournament%20Wrap.ashx "Australian Open Championships tournament wrap"] from ''Cricket Australia'' The national competition in New Zealand is referred to as the Tri Series and is contested by three provinces – Northern, Central and Southern.[http://www.nzindoorsports.org.nz/130/ "Tri-Series results"] from ''NZ Indoor Sports'' National championships contested elsewhere in the world include South Africa's National Championship[http://www.indoorcricketsa.co.za/pages/juniorst/ "National Championships"] from ''Indoor Cricket South Africa'' and England's National League.[http://www.ecbic.co.uk/national/national-league/ "National League"] from ''ECB Indoor Cricket'' ===Minor Competition=== In addition to social competition played throughout the world there are several state leagues and competitions within each nation.[http://www.ecbic.co.uk/national/british-pen/ "British Open"] from ''ECB Indoor Cricket'' Various states, provinces or geographical areas organise their own state championships (referred to in Australia as "Superleague" – not to be confused with the [[Super League (Australia)|ill-fated Rugby League competition]]). Various districts, centres or arenas take part in these competitions.[http://indoorsportsvictoria.com.au/competitions/superleague/superleague-indoor-cricket.php "Superleague"] from ''Indoor Sports Victoria'' ===World Cup=== {{Main|Indoor Cricket World Cup}} The Indoor Cricket World cup was first held in Birmingham, England in 1995 and has run every two or three years since. The event usually also features age-group, masters' and women's competitions. The last World Cup was held in Wellington (NZ) in October 2014. Australia came first in the boys', girls', women's and men's competitions. Australia has won all 9 Open Men World Cup titles (since 1995) and all 8 Open World Cup titles (since 1998).[http://cricket.com.au/default.aspx?s=news-display&id=17476 "2009 world cup results"] from ''Cricket Australia'' ==Origin and development of indoor cricket== The first significant example of organised indoor cricket took place, somewhat unusually, in Germany. A tournament was held under the auspices of the [[Husum Cricket Club]] in a hall in [[Flensburg]] in the winter of 1968–69. It was not until the 1970s that the game began to take shape as a codified sport. Conceived as a way of keeping cricketers involved during the winter months, various six-a-side leagues were formed throughout England in the first half of the decade, eventually leading to the first national competition held in March 1976 at the Sobell Center in Islington. This distinct form of indoor cricket is [[Indoor cricket (UK variant)|still played today]]. Despite the early popularity of the sport in England, a different version of indoor cricket developed by two different parties in [[Perth, Western Australia]] in the late 1970s evolved into the sport known as indoor cricket today. Against the backdrop of the upheaval in the conventional game caused by World Series Cricket, torrential rain and a desire to keep their charges active led cricket school administrators [[Dennis Lillee]] and [[Graeme Monaghan]] to set up netted arenas indoors. Concurrently, entrepreneurs [[Paul Hanna]] and [[Michael Jones (entrepreneur)|Michael Jones]] began creating an eight-a-side game that eventually led to the nationwide franchise known as [[Indoor Cricket Arenas]] (ICA). It was not long before hundreds of ICA-branded stadiums were set up throughout Australia, leading to the first national championships held in 1984 at a time where over 200,000 people were estimated to be participating in the sport.[http://www.worldindoorcricketfederation.com World Indoor Cricket Federation] Nations may either be full members or associate members of the WICF.[http://worldindoorcricketfederation.com/countries.html "Countries"] from ''WICF'' Each member nation has its own national body which regulates matches played in its country. The national bodies are responsible for selecting representatives for its national side and organising home and away internationals for the side. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Nation !Governing body !Member status |- | {{cr|AUS}} | [[Cricket Australia]] | Full Member |- | {{cr|ENG}} | [[England and Wales Cricket Board]] | Full Member |- | {{cr|IND}} | [[Board of Control for Cricket in India]] | Full Member |- | {{cr|NZ}} | [[New Zealand Indoor Sports]] | Full Member |- | {{cr|RSA}} | [[Indoor Cricket South Africa]] | Full Member |- | {{cr|SRI}} | Ceylon Indoor Cricket Association | Full Member |- | {{cr|Singapore}} | [[Indoor Cricket Singapore]] | Associate Member |- | {{cr|Wales}} | [[England and Wales Cricket Board]] | Associate Member |} ==Other forms of indoor cricket== ===Conventional cricket indoors=== Conventional cricket matches have taken place at covered venues (usually featuring a retractable roof) and can thus be regarded as cricket being played indoors. Such matches are relatively infrequent and come with added complications in the event that the ball makes contact with the roof while in play.[http://www.sportal.com.au/cricket-news-display/roof-hits-now-a-six-214674 "Roof hits now a six in BBL"] from ''Sportal'', accessed 28 January 2012 ===UK variant=== {{Main|Indoor cricket (UK variant)}} A version of indoor cricket (bearing greater resemblance to conventional cricket) is played exclusively in the United Kingdom. This variant sees the six players on each team utilise the same playing and protective equipment that can be found in outdoor cricket, and is played in indoor facilities that differ greatly from the international form of indoor cricket.[http://static.ecb.co.uk/files/2925-nfc-six-a-side-2012-p47-54-lr-11959.pdf "Competition Rules"] from ''ECB Indoor Club Championships'', accessed 28 January 2013 Despite lacking international competition, this form of indoor cricket enjoys a strong following in the UK, and, like its international counterpart, enjoys the support of the [[England and Wales Cricket Board|ECB]][http://www.ecb.co.uk/news/non-first-class/ecb-indoor-six-a-side-championship/lords-joy-for-whitstable,317213,EN.html?Pf=com.otherobjects.cms.model.structure.Folder-L-258 "Lord's joy for Whitstable"] from ''ECB'', accessed 28 January 2013 ==See also== *[[Arena Football]] *[[Indoor Soccer]] *[[Box Lacrosse]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.worldindoorcricketfederation.com/ World Indoor Cricket Federation] '''National Bodies''' * [http://www.indoor.cricket.com.au/ Cricket Australia - Indoor] * [http://www.nzindoorsports.org.nz/ New Zealand Indoor Sports] ** [http://www.indoorcricketnz.org.nz/ Indoor Cricket New Zealand] * [http://www.ecbic.co.uk/ Indoor Cricket England] * [http://www.indoorcricketsa.co.za/ Indoor Cricket South Africa] * [http://indoorcricketusa.com/ Indoor Cricket USA] '''Australian State Bodies''' * [http://www.cricketact.com/ Cricket ACT] * [http://www.bulls.com.au/ Cricket Queensland] * [http://www.indoorsportsnsw.org.au/ Indoor Sports New South Wales] * [http://www.indoorsportsvictoria.com.au/ Indoor Sports Victoria] * [http://www.indoorsportswa.com/ Indoor Sports Western Australia] '''New Zealand Provincial Bodies''' * [http://www.indoorcricketnz.org.nz/indoor-centres/nothern-region/ Northern Indoor Cricket] * [http://www.indoorcricketnz.org.nz/indoor-centres/central-region/ Central Indoor Cricket] * [http://www.indoorcricketnz.org.nz/indoor-centres/southern-region/ Southern Indoor Cricket] '''Other Links''' * [http://www.indoorcricketworld.net/What/rules/ The Rules of Indoor Cricket] - Indoor Cricket World * [http://www.indoor.cricket.com.au/files/17000/files/Match%20Rules%20and%20Regulations.pdf Indoor Cricket Australian Championships Match Rules and Regulations], April 2015 * [https://www.indoorleagues.co.uk Indoor Leagues UK] {{Forms of cricket}} {{Team Sport}} [[Category:Indoor cricket|*]] [[Category:Short form cricket]] [[Category:Indoor sports|Cricket]] [[Category:Sports originating in Australia]]

===2004 Athens Olympics=== {{main|Boxing at the 2004 Summer Olympics}} One amateur boxer represented Japan to the 2004 Olympics. He was defeated in his first match by Endalkachew Kebede of [[Ethiopia]].

Winning one bronze medal, Japan is ranked 11th<ref>[http://doha-2006.com Boxing standings]</ref> in a four-way tie with [[North Korea|DPR Korea]], [[Syria]] and the host country [[Qatar]].

'''Liga Georgina de Villegas''' is a [[basketball]] [[Sports league|league]] from [[San Pedro Sula]], [[Honduras]]. Even though based in San Pedro Sula, it is referred to as the metropolitan league because it includes [[team]]s from [[La Lima]], [[El Progreso]] and [[La Ceiba]]. It is considered the top league in the [[north]] and one of the most elite in the [[country]]. It is actually comprised both by a [[male]] and a [[female]] league. The male league is divided into two divisions with a [[promotion and relegation]] system every year.2008 season results ==2008 season== === The current champions===

revision.text:
{{infobox country at games | NOC = MLI | NOCname = Comité National Olympique et Sportif du Mali | games = Summer Olympics | year = 2012 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = [[London]] | competitors = 6 | sports = 4 | flagbearer = [[Rahamatou Drame]] | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Mali]]''' competed at the '''[[2012 Summer Olympic Games]]''' in [[London]], from 27 July to 12 August 2012. This was the nation's twelfth appearance at the Olympics, it was not represented at the [[1976 Summer Olympics]] in Montreal because of the African boycott. As no Malian teams qualified for the team events, Mali sent its smallest delegation to the Games after the [[2000 Summer Olympics]] in Sydney. Six Malian athletes, 4 men and 2 women, were selected to the team to compete in 4 sports. Hurdler [[Rahamatou Drame]], who competed at her first Olympic games, was the nation's flag bearer at the opening ceremony. Mali, however, has yet to win its first ever Olympic medal. Taekwondo jin and double-time world heavyweight champion [[Daba Modibo Keita]] missed out of the nation's historic Olympic record, after he withdrew from the bronze medal tournament because of the injuries he had sustained.{{cite news|title=Cuba's Despaigne, Mexico's Espinoza take taekwondo {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Sammy Ofer Stadium | nickname: = Avi Ran Stadium, Haifa Stadium | image = File:PikiWiki Israel 49197 Sports in Israel.jpg | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA]]''' {{rating|4|4}} | fullname = Sammy Ofer Stadium | location = [[Haifa]], [[Israel]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2009 | built = | opened = 27 August 2014 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Haifa|City of Haifa]] | operator = [[Haifa|City of Haifa]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Israeli new shekel|₪]]530 million | services engineer = | general_contractor= | main_contractors = | architect = [[KSS Design Group]] | tenants = [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] (2014–present)
[[Hapoel Haifa F.C.|Hapoel Haifa]] (2014–present)
[[Israel national football team]] | seating_capacity = 30,780[https://www.haifa-stadium.com/Facts_and_Numbers Official stadium website] | dimensions = 22.000 Sq m }} The '''Sammy Ofer Stadium''' ({{lang-he|אצטדיון סמי עופר}}), also known as '''Haifa International Stadium''' ({{lang-he| האצטדיון העירוני חיפה}}), is a 30,780 seats [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Haifa]], [[Israel]].[http://www.kssgroup.com/projects/sammy-ofer-stadium.php www.kssgroup.com] Construction began in late 2009 and was completed in 2014. The stadium was developed and built by the Haifa Economic Corporation, managed by Adv. Gal Peleg. Currently, the stadium is used mostly for [[Association football|football]] matches, hosting the home games of [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] and [[Hapoel Haifa F.C.]] The stadium replaced [[Kiryat Eliezer Stadium]], which was closed in 2014 and demolished in 2015. The stadium is named after the late Israeli billionaire [[Sammy Ofer]], who donated [[United States dollar|$]]20,000,000 to build the stadium. Ofer's contribution was 19% of the total cost of the stadium. ==History== On September 16, 2008, the Haifa Construction Committee approved the stadium's plans and gave it the green light. On August 2009, official plans of the stadium released. On September 2009, it has been announced that the works on building the foundations of the stadium would begin at the end of September 2009. The first official match ever at Sammy Ofer Stadium was played on August 27, 2014. [[Hapoel Haifa]] hosted Hapoel Acre (TOTO CUP) and won 2–0. The first historic goal in the new stadium was scored by Hapoel Haifa striker [[Tosaint Ricketts]]. The first league match was played on September 15, 2014. [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] hosted [[Bnei Sakhnin F.C.]], who they defeated by a score of 4–2. The historic first goal by a Maccabi Haifa player was scored by Israeli national team midfielder [[Hen Ezra]] during stoppage time of the first half. Over 31,000 supporters were in attendance.http://maccabi-haifafc.walla.co.il/?w=/3036/2785849 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225210835/http://maccabi-haifafc.walla.co.il/?w=%2F3036%2F2785849 |date=2014-12-25 }} The first [[UEFA Champions League]] match was played on September 30, 2015 by [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] against [[Dinamo Kiev]],http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000634/match=2015685/postmatch/report/index.html Dinamo won 2–0 by goles [[Andriy Yarmolenko]] and [[Júnior Moraes]] . The first match of the [[Israel national football team]] was played on November 16, 2014. Israel hosted the [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team]] in the [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match and won the match by a score of 3–0. The stadium was sold out, which resulted in an atmosphere beyond compare, helping Israel win their 3rd game in a row in the tournament.https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/11/16/europe/european-championship-qualification/israel/bosnia-herzegovina/1653243/?ICID=PL_MS_24 [[Image:Sammy Ofer Stadium panorama.JPG|center|thumb|800px|Sammy Ofer Stadium]] The first concert at the stadium was of [[Omer Adam]] on May 24, 2018. ==International matches== {| class="wikitable" ! Date !! !! Result !! !! Competition !! {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Seminole Soccer Complex | nickname = | image = [[File:SeminoleSoccer.JPG|300px]] | location = Spirit Way
[[Tallahassee, Florida]] 32304 | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1998 | built = | opened = 1999 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Florida State University]] | operator = [[Florida State University Athletics|Florida State Athletics]] | surface = Natural Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | general_contractor = | former_names = | tenants = [[Florida State Seminoles women's soccer]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) | seating_capacity = 2,000 | record_attendance = 4,582 }} The '''Seminole Soccer Complex''' is the on-campus [[soccer]] stadium at [[Florida State University]] in [[Tallahassee, Florida]]. The 2,000-seat stadium was built in 1998. The current tenants are the [[Florida State Seminoles women's soccer]] team, who are 170-37-14 at home ==Championships== The women's soccer team won the 2014 National Championship with a 1-0 win over the [[University of Virginia]] and the 2018 National Championship with 1-0 win over the [[University of North Carolina]]. ==See also== *[[Florida State Seminoles]] *[[Florida State Seminoles women's soccer]] *[[History of Florida State University]] *[[List of Florida State University people#Athletes|List of Florida State University professional athletes]] ==External links== * [http://www.seminoles.com/SportSelect.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=32900&SPID=157114&SPSID=917036&DB_OEM_ID=32900 Seminoles.com] – Official website of the Florida State Seminoles women's soccer team. * [http://seminoles.cstv.com/facilities/fsu-soccer-complex.html Seminole Soccer Complex website] {{coord|28.794554|-81.389168|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Florida State University}} {{ACC Soccer-Lacrosse Facilities}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Florida]] [[Category:Florida State University]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tallahassee, Florida]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Florida]] {{Florida-sports-venue-stub}} {{TallahasseeFL-stub}}

[[File:Dr. Steven Ungerleider, Dick Pound.jpg|thumb|Steven Ungerleider (left) at the presentation of the humanitarian award to [[Dick Pound]] (right), February 2010]]
'''Steven Ungerleider''' is an American [[sports psychologist]], author, and documentary film producer.
Ungerleider is a graduate of the [[University of Texas at Austin]]. He holds the PhD from the [[University of Oregon]]. As an undergraduate, he competed in gymnastics for Texas.<ref name=UniversityWebsite>{{cite web|title=Steven Ungerleider|url=http://www.hrc.utexas.edu/contribute/advisory/bios/steven_ungerleider.html|website=utexas.edu|publisher=University of Texas|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref>
Ungerleider's documentary film, [[Munich 1972 & Beyond]], is scheduled for release in 2016.<ref name=Jaffee>{{cite news|last1=Jaffee|first1=Maayan|title=After decades of IOC silence, slain Israeli Olympians headed for recognition|url=http://www.jns.org/latest-articles/2015/5/22/after-decades-of-ioc-silence-slain-israeli-olympians-headed-for-recognition#.Vl3zSHs2uHk=|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=JNS.org|date=22 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Zaccardi>{{cite news|last1=Zaccardi|first1=Nick|title=Munich 1972 Olympic attack victims' families detail massacre in documentary|url=http://olympics.nbcsports.com/2015/12/01/munich-olympics-terrorist-attacks-documentary-1972/|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=NBC Sports|date=1 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=Borden>{{cite news|last1=Borden|first1=Sam|title=Long-Hidden Details Reveal Cruelty of 1972 Munich Attackers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/02/sports/long-hidden-details-reveal-cruelty-of-1972-munich-attackers.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=second-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=1 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=APA>{{cite news|title=Psychologist's documentary focuses on the 1972 Munich Massacre|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/2015/07-08/upfront-munich.aspx|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=American Psychological Association|date=July 2015}}</ref>
== Films == * 2015 - ''Munich '72 and Beyond'' - Producer<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.jfcs.org/munich-72-and-beyond-will-screen-at-jewish-family-childrens-services-in-san-francisco/|title="Munich ’72 and Beyond" Documentary from The Foundation for Global Sports Development Will Screen at Jewish Family & Children’s Services in San Francisco - JFCS|date=2016-06-14|work=JFCS|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> * 2017 - ''End Game'' - Executive Producer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sundance.org/projects/end-game#/|title=end-game|website=www.sundance.org|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> * 2018 – ''At the Heart of Gold: Inside the USA Gymnastics Scandal'' – Producer<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://deadline.com/2018/07/hbo-acquires-documentary-usa-gymnastics-scandal-1202436554/|title=HBO Acquires Documentary On USA Gymnastics Sexual-Abuse Scandal|last=Pedersen|first=Erik|date=2018-07-30|work=Deadline|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Books== * Quest For Success (WRS/Spence Publications, 1994) * Mental Training For Peak Performance (Rodale Press, 1996) * Faust's Gold: Inside the East German Doping Machine (St.Martin's Press)<ref name=Longman>{{cite news|last1=Longman|first1=Jere|title=Just Following Orders, Doctors' Orders (book review)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/22/sports/just-following-orders-doctors-orders.html|accessdate=2 December 2015|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=22 April 2001}}</ref> * Beyond Strength (McGraw-Hill, 1991) with co-author Dr. Jacqueline Golding
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7CKN45BzYU Munich Memorial Project Interview with Dr. Steven Ungerleider]

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport governing body |name = UAE Chess Federation
اتحاد الامارات للشطرنج |abbrev = UAECF |logo = UAEChess Federation.PNG |logosize = 150px |sport = [[Chess]] |category = |image = |caption = |jurisdiction = [[UAE]] |founded = {{Start date|1976}} |aff = [[FIDE]]
[[Asian Chess Federation]]
[[Arab Chess Federation]] |headquarters = [[Dubai]] |location = |president = [[Ph. D. Sarhan Hassan Almuaini]] |chairman = |chairperson = |chair = |chiefexec = |vicepresident = [[Abdulaziz Abdulla Khouri]] |director = |secretary = [[Hussain Khalfan Alshamsi]] |coach = |womenscoach = |key staff = |operating income = |sponsor = |year closed = |replaced = |prevfounded = |url = |countryflag = UAE |countryflag2 = |countryflag3 = |more = }} '''United Arab Emirates Chess Federation''' ('''UAECF''') was established in October 1976 to spread and develop the game of [[chess]] as a mental and cultural sport across the [[United Arab Emirates]]. It organizes national tournaments such as the [[Emirati Chess Championship]]. The UAECF took part in the [[Against Chess Olympiad]] held in [[Libya]] in 1976. In 1977, it became a member of FIDE. Later on, chess started to spread across all Emirates and chess clubs were set up in [[Dubai]], [[Sharjah (city)|Sharjah]], [[Abu Dhabi]], [[Ajman]], [[Fujairah]] and [[Al-Ain]]. [[Chess & Culture Club for Sharjah Women]] was opened in 1991 and another club for women was affiliated with [[Dubai Chess and Culture Club]] in 2000. now there are 16 club officially registered in UAE chess federation. All these clubs play a key role in the discovery and training the young talents, and later on UAECF choose the best players for the national teams, where they come for training under supervision of head coach of UAECF. ==Major achievements== Emirati native [[Saeed Ahmed Saeed]] won the 1979 [[World Youth Chess Championship#Under-14 winners|Under-14 World Chess Championship]] held in [[Mexico]] and this was the first achievement for UAE in chess at the international level. He repeated the feat in 1981 and was referred to in Arab media as "The Arab computer." Rouda Essa Alserkal recently had the world title as (( world chess championship Under 8 girls, 2017 in Brazil)). == See also == * [[Arab Chess Federation]] == External links == * {{Official website|url=http://www.uaechess.com/default.aspx?lang=en}} [[Category:Chess organizations]] [[Category:Chess in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:1976 in chess]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1976]] [[Category:1976 establishments in the United Arab Emirates]] {{UnitedArabEmirates-sport-stub}} {{Chess-org-stub}}

[[Fatih Karagümrük]]
[[Vefa SK]] | seating_capacity = 12,500 (all seated) {{cite news|url= http://www.fatihkaragumruk.org/fatihkaragumruk.asp?s_id=4#Stad%C4%B1m%C4%B1z |publisher=fatihkaragumruk.org |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= |title= Stadımız|language=tr}}
6,500 (pre-construction) | dimensions = }} '''Vefa Stadı''' ({{lang-en|Vefa Stadium}}) (also named '''Karagümrük Stadı/Arena''') is a [[football (soccer)|football]] stadium, home ground of Turkish Regional Amateur League teams [[Fatih Karagümrük]],{{cite news|url= http://www.tff.org/Default.aspx?pageID=28&kulupID=3611 |publisher=tff.org |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= |title= Vefa - Fatih Karagümrük|language=tr}} located in [[Karagümrük]],{{cite news|url= http://www.uzaydanbak.com/points/details/100276 |publisher=uzaydanbak.com|accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= |title= Fatih Karagümrük Stadı, Istanbul|language=tr}} [[Istanbul]].{{cite news|url= http://www.tff.org/Default.aspx?pageID=28&kulupID=3611 |publisher=tff.org |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= |title= Stat Bilgileri: Vefa|language=tr}} Vefa Stadı is occasionally in use for the promotional play-off enocunters in lower tier leagues, other sports including [[American Football]]{{cite news|url= http://www.nfltr.com/tr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=222:kuluepler-ligi-finali-vefa-stadnda&catid=49:tafl&Itemid=169 |publisher=nfltr.com |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= 2009-05-28|title= Kulüpler Ligi Finali Vefa Stadı'nda!|language=tr}} and for [[Public holidays in Turkey|public holiday ceremonies]]. ==History== Karagümrük Stadium was initially used as a football home ground in 1926, in the middle of a dip garden waves from [[Byzantium|Byzantium Era]], called [[Çukurbostan]] in Çukurbostan district of Fatih. Stadium is constructed in ''[[Cistern of Aetius|Aetius Cistern]]'', on Fevzi Paşa Caddesi ({{lang-en|Fevzi Paşa Avenue}}), heading to [[Edirnekapı, Istanbul|Edirnekapı]] district of Fatih.{{cite news|url= http://www.kenthaber.com/Haber/Genel/Kose/yilmaz-erguvenc/vefa-stadi--/cfbfd111-a6a9-4861-9dce-328d09522e31|publisher=kenthaber.com |accessdate=2011-09-19 |year= 2008|title= Vefa Stadı |language=tr}} Due to the Byzantiumeferences, the cistern is built in [[AD]] 420, by praetorian prefect [[Aetius (praetorian prefect)|Aetius]] during the rule of [[Theodosius II]] (reigned between 408 – 450). The cistern is 244x84 m. and 15 m. deeper than surface, surrounded by 15 m. high walls. Due to the archeological importance of the cistern, the walls had been protected at the initial stadium project. The conversion had been started in 1926. In 1945, when the stadium construction was finalized, the tenant rights were taken over by [[Hasan Âli Yücel]], an alumnus of [[Vefa Lisesi]] and former [[Ministry of National Education (Turkey)|Minister of National Education]], and given to by [[Vefa SK]],an other football club of the district; as Stadium also was renamed Vefa Stadı. ===Renovation=== The renovation of stadium has begun to be conducted in 2007, with 30.000.000 [[New Turkish Lira|TRY]] grand cost,{{cite news|url=http://v3.arkitera.com/news.php?action=displayNewsItem&ID=22900 |publisher=arkitera.com |author= |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= 2007-12-10|title= Belediye’den Vefa Stadı’na vefa!..|language=tr}} consisting 11.722 seated 3 all-covered stands (including 7.648 behind the goal, 1.024 for away side and 24 seats for visitors), one 66m2 VIP lodge, 6 normal lodges, and a 682 seats capacity VIP stand.{{cite news|url=http://www.tumgazeteler.com/?a=2441171 |publisher=tumgazeteler.com |author= Kılıç, Yasin |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= 2007-12-23|title= Karagümrük Stadı spor kompleksine dönüştürülecek|language=tr}} The project{{cite news|url=http://sunumer.ibb.gov.tr/karagumruk-stadi-spor-kompleksi |publisher=ibb.gov.tr |author= |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= 2007-12-10|title= TKaragümrük Stadı Spor Kompleksi|language=tr}} also includes [[basketball]], [[table tennis]], and [[martial arts]] facilities.{{cite news|url=http://www.tumgazeteler.com/?a=2420792 |publisher=tumgazeteler.com |author= |accessdate=2011-09-19 |date= 2007-12-23|title= Tarihi Karagümrük Stadı kompleks oluyor|language=tr}} [[Image:Vefastadi4.jpg|right|thumb|260px|Stadium view from the avenue]] ==See also== * [[Cistern of Aetius]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.tff.org/Default.aspx?pageID=28&kulupID=3611 Stadium Profile] at [[Turkish Football Federation|TFF]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Vefa Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Sports venues in Istanbul]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1926]] [[Category:Sport in Fatih]]
